awd_titl_txt: A Holistic View of Gas, Dust, and Metals in Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
The gas between stars is part of the interstellar medium (ISM) and is fundamental to understanding how galaxies evolve. However, the gas often can only be studied by indirect methods, and the most widely used tracer is emission from carbon monoxide (CO). This project will advance the understanding of CO and dust as tracers, using new observations of nearby galaxies from the Hubble Space Telescope, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array, and other facilities. The team will study the CO emission from the ISM of the Magellanic Clouds, as well as the ISM in the centers of nearby galaxies. They will conduct a series of summer workshops designed to help transfer students moving from community colleges to UC San Diego. Transfer students are a diverse, highly motivated group, disadvantaged by the compressed timeline after transferring, and removing these barriers is a key step in broadening the participation of under-represented groups. 

Indirect methods are needed because most of the hydrogen molecules are too cold to produce emission lines. Calibrating CO emission as a tracer requires understanding several parameters: the dust-to-gas ratio as a function of metallicity, the relation between dust emission and dust mass at a given temperature, and the conversion between CO and hydrogen, all of which vary with conditions in the ISM. The new observations will be brought together to create an applicable prescription for dust emissivity, dust-to-gas ratio, and conversion factor, as a function of environment. This will allow assessment of the ISM gas content over the full range from the Milky Way to distant high-redshift galaxies, and help to remove inescapable systematic uncertainties intrinsic to the current approach. The work should yield new insights into the physical state of the ISM in galaxies, including the arrangement of molecular clouds and their response to galactic environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Stars form in dense, cold clouds of interstellar gas and dust.  In these conditions, most of the hydrogen is in the form of molecules (H2), and we call these regions molecular clouds.  In the cold temperatures present in molecular clouds, the H2 molecule itself does not emit because it is too cold to excite its rotational or vibrational emission.  To trace where H2 is and to learn about how efficiently it forms stars, astronomers instead use the emission from the second most abundant molecule in the interstellar medium (ISM), carbon monoxide (CO). Observing H2 thus involves mapping CO emission and then using a “CO-to-H2 conversion factor” to convert to molecular gas mass.  However, the conversion factor appears to vary across galaxies.  The main objective of this proposal was to improve our understanding of the CO-to-H2 conversion factor variation across galaxies.  In Teng et al. (2022), we developed a technique to measure the conversion factor and molecular gas properties using emission from CO and its “isotopologues” (13CO, C18O).  We used this technique in Teng et al. (2023) to map the conversion factor in the centers of three nearby galaxies.  We found that the conversion factor is lower than the typical value in these galaxy centers, partially due to influences of the local environment on molecular clouds.  We also investigated the conversion factor using interstellar dust to trace where gas is. This is possible because dust and gas are well-mixed together in the ISM, regardless of whether the gas is primarily just H or if it is H2.  Using a comprehensive sample of galaxies where dust-based measurements are possible, we mapped the conversion factor across 37 galaxies in Chiang et al. (2024).  Here again we saw changes in the conversion factor that appear to be related to the local galactic environment.  Combining these new insights, in Teng et al. (2024) and Chiang et al. (2024) we created a new prescriptions for the CO-to-H2 conversion factor that depend on the local environment.  Finally, in Teng et al. (2024) we used these new prescriptions to investigate how the efficiency of star formation from molecular gas varies across 75 nearby galaxies.  We found that galaxies with bars (enhancements in stellar density that occur in a large fraction of massive galaxies) have more efficient star formation in their centers, which is important for understanding their morphology and evolution.

 

In addition, the PI led a series of workshops to provide training in research skills for incoming community college transfer students in the Physical Sciences at UC San Diego.  Community college transfer students are a diverse, highly motivated cohort, many of whom have ambitions to continue their studies in graduate school.  Undergraduate research experience is a key step along the path to graduate school. However, due to their compressed timeline after transferring, many transfer students face challenges in obtaining research experience. The PI led a series of 5 workshops during the first weeks of the Fall quarter to provide new transfer students in Physical Sciences (Math, Chemistry, Physics, Astronomy & Astrophysics) with training in key research skills and mentorship in finding new research opportunities.  The workshops involved training in reading academic papers, programming in python, LaTeX, computer skills, accessing scientific literature, applying to summer research opportunities, and finding research opportunities during the academic quarter at UC San Diego. Along with other faculty members at UC San Diego and San Diego State University, the PI has started a new summer research program for community college transfer students in Astronomy & Astrophysics. This program, called STARTastro (“Summer Transfer Academy and Research Training in Astronomy & Astrophysics”), includes 2 weeks of academic and research skills preparation and then 6 weeks working on a research project.  The first cohort of students participated in Summer 2024.
